facts.text: Waqf properties in Monghyr District dedicated by Sheikh Golam Yahya by registered Waqfnama dated April 11, 1870. Mutwallis chosen from descendants in male line generation to generation. First Mutwalli was Waqif.
After Waqif's death, his wife held charge of the Toliat. After her death, appellant's father and from 1930 the appellant were Mutwallis. Mutwalli entitled to 9/48th share of income as remuneration.
Bihar Waqfs Act, 1947 (Act 8 of 1948) came into force on April 1, 1948. Waqf registered as Waqf No. 67. Bihar Subai Sunni Majlis-e-Awqaf (Majlis) began supervising.
Syed Bashiruddin was Sadr (Chairman) of Majlis. Syed Mehdi Hassan was Nazir-e-Awqaf under S.22.

On March 2, 1949, Syed Naziruddin Ashraf (step-brother of appellant) and others presented application for removal of appellant from Mutwalliship on charges including mismanagement, misappropriation, waste, falsification of accounts etc. Registered as Case No. 37 of 1949.
Enquiry by Mehdi Hassan, reported on May 25, 1950 to Majlis that charges proved.
Majlis meeting August 20, 1950: notice to appellant to show cause why removed. Appellant showed cause.
Nazir submitted second report on October 15, 1950.
Appellant examined. On November 28, 1950, Sadr passed order agreeing with Nazir's report, confirming findings of mismanagement etc.
Auditor appointed, reported on February 8, 1951 that Rs. 9682/1/3 due from appellant to Waqf.
Sadr ordered appellant to deposit amount by April 2, 1951.
Appellant failed to deposit. On June 28, 1951, Sadr removed appellant and appointed Maulvi Mohammad Shoeb as Mutwalli for one year under s.32, directed to take charge.
Appellant applied to District Judge under s.27(3) to set aside Sadr's order, also sought removal of Shoeb. Registered Misc. Case No. 30/4 of 1951.
Four issues before District Judge: (1) Jurisdiction over pre-Act accounts/enquiries; (2) Jurisdiction to remove; (3) Jurisdiction to appoint Shoeb; (4) Ss.27,32 ultra vires.

Additional District Judge held against appellant on issues 1,2,4; issue 3 against (appointment vacated as needed ratification). Rejected new point on s.27(2)(h)(iii) not retrospective from June 6, 1951.
Two appeals by appellant and Shoeb; revision by Majlis/Shoeb. High Court Dec 21, 1960: dismissed appellant's appeal, accepted Shoeb's.
Bihar Waqfs Amendment Act 1951 (Act 18) assented May 24, 1951, inserted words in s.27(2)(h).
Previous case: Bashiruddin Ashraf v. State of Bihar, s.58 upheld.

legal_issues.text: Whether Majlis/Sadr competent to direct Mutwalli to produce pre-Act accounts, hold enquiries, pass removal orders based on pre-Act events?
Whether Majlis/Sadr had jurisdiction to remove appellant on grounds in order dated June 28, 1951?
Whether Majlis/Sadr competent to appoint temporary Mutwalli (Maulvi Shoeb)?
Whether ss.27 and 32 of Bihar Waqfs Act ultra vires Constitution?
Whether s.27(2)(h)(iii) added by 1951 Amendment retrospective, applicable only post-June 6, 1951?
Whether Sadr could exercise Majlis powers under ss.37,38 for removal?

petitioner_arguments.text: Majlis/Sadr lacked jurisdiction over pre-Act accounts/enquiries/removal.
S.27(2)(h)(iii) not retrospective; power only for post-amendment disobedience.
Order actuated by bias, prejudice, malafides; erroneous on merits/evidence.
Sadr lacked power to act without delegation/emergency under ss.37,38.
Pre-amendment clause had 'directions' not 'orders'; disobedience of orders pre-amendment not covered.

respondent_arguments.text: S.32 allows temporary appointment by Majlis without prior/subsequent court assent; endures till contrary order.
Charges of mismanagement proved by Nazir, accepted by Sadr, District Judge, High Court.

court_reasoning.text: High Court correctly held s.32 confers jurisdiction on Majlis for temporary appointment; 'subject to any order by competent court' means endures till contrary order.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No prior permission or assent needed.

court_reasoning.text: Will not re-examine facts/merits; charges proved at all levels; fair trial; deprecate alleging High Court ignored arguments without proof.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Finality to High Court fact findings.

court_reasoning.text: Amendment confers prospective jurisdiction but exercisable on pre-amendment disobedience; otherwise no jurisdiction post-amendment. No vested right to continue after misconduct.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power reaches back to past conduct if intended.

court_reasoning.text: 'Orders and directions' differ in degree only; disobedience of either merits removal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No distinction punishing one but not other.

court_reasoning.text: S.37 allows Sadr emergency powers; ss.37,38 applicable; removal necessary due to disobedience/non-deposit.
Ss.27,32 not unconstitutional; previous challenge to s.58 failed.

holdings.text: Majlis/Sadr had jurisdiction to enquire pre-Act matters, remove for disobedience including pre-amendment.
Amendment s.27(2)(h) prospective but applies to past conduct/disobedience.
Sadr exercised Majlis powers validly under ss.37/38.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bashiruddin Ashraf v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Held s.58 of Bihar Waqfs Act valid.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Waqfs Act, 1947 (Act 8 of 1948)
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers of Majlis/Sadr for supervision, removal of Mutwalli for disobedience, temporary appointment, emergency delegation; challenged as ultra vires but upheld.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Waqfs (Amendment) Act, 1951 (Act 18 of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Inserted words enabling Majlis direct removal for wilful disobedience; prospective but applicable to past conduct.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Alleged violation by Waqfs Act provisions; rejected.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed. Removal of appellant as Mutwalli upheld. High Court's restoration of temporary Mutwalli appointment under s.32 affirmed. No merit in jurisdictional or constitutional challenges.

key_quotes.text: "A statute is not necessarily used retrospectively when the power conferred by it is based on conduct anterior to its enactment, if it is clearly intended that the said power must reach back to that conduct."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on amendment's application to past disobedience.

key_quotes.text: "The words in that section subject to any order by the competent court did not mean that there had to be either prior permission or subsequent assent before the appointment was complete."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "There could be no vested right to continue as Mutwalli after mismanagement and misconduct of many sorts were established."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects retrospectivity bar due to no vested right.
